awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  NSF/EAR-BSF: Coupled Sand and Clay Motion, Bed Morphodynamics, and Porewater Exchange
awd_abstract_narration:
Interactions between water and sediments shape water bodies, set habitat for fish, shellfish, and other aquatic organisms, and control land stability in river floodplains and coastal regions. While the behavior of sandy systems is fairly well understood, little information is available on interactions between sand and finer sediments such as clay and mud. Mixed clay-sand deposits are very common in rivers and coastal estuaries, yet it is not currently possible to predict important behavior of clay-sand mixtures, such as changes in sand dunes, beaches, and channels following shoreline erosion. This project will advance capability to measure and predict interactions between water flow, sand, and clay in freshwater and marine systems. This capability will enable better management of critical U.S. water resources, reduce damage from coastal erosion, and facilitate shipping and military operations in shallow coastal waters. 

This project aims to show that clay-sand-water coupling follows a regular and fundamental set of processes:  migration of clay into sand beds, accumulation of clay deposits, and feedbacks from clay filling pore spaces and cementing sand grains. Work will be conducted jointly by U.S. and Israeli research teams. Experiments will use a suite of new optical, acoustic, and X-ray imaging methods to measure water flow, clay-sand dynamics, and sediment bed formation. These results will be used to develop new mathematical theory and computer models enabling prediction of water flow and sediment dynamics in clay-sand systems.

This award is cofunded by the Geomorphology and Land-use Dynamics Program, the Hydrologic Sciences Program, and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

inst.inst_name: Nevada System of Higher Education, Desert Research Institute

por.por_cntn:
In the last few decades, it has become clear that rivers are not just conduits of water and sediment from one place to another, but rather, play an important role in local to global biogeochemical cycles. In particular, riverbeds are centers of microbial and chemical processing that affect water quality and river ecosystem health. Riverbeds are an important part of the carbon cycle and can temporarily store nutrients, pathogens, and contaminants.  However, riverbeds are not static; their composition and structure can change with river flows and seasons, affecting the processes that occur within.

In this project, researchers from the Desert Research Institute, Northwestern University, and Ben Gurion University collaborated to investigate how morphology and structure of river systems changes as varying amounts of clay clog and unclog the riverbed due to changes in porewater exchange. We conducted experiments to measure water flow and the associated migration of dissolved solutes and suspended particles in laboratory flumes in both Evanston, Illinois and Sde Boker, Israel.  

After studying the effects of clay deposition on riverbed mobility and hyporheic exchange, we completed a series of laboratory and numerical experiments on moving bedforms across a range of salinities and flow strengths. We found that coupled clay-sand motion in a small stream depends on storage within bedforms. Clay deposition results in decreased bedform amplitude, bedform velocity, and sediment transport rates. At longer timescales, accumulation of clay just below the depth of bedform scour stabilizes the bed sediment and reduces water exchange between the bed and channel. Overall clay-sand interactions are controlled by coupling between hyporheic exchange that causes clay deposition, clay accumulation that stabilizes the sand bed sediment and reduces sediment transport rates, and bedform scour that remobilizes clay and restores sand mobility. Depending on river conditions, the bed either becomes mobile or locks, affecting the length of time that clay particles are stored in the beds.

We found that clogging can happen during constant flow conditions due to the coupling of clay particles and hyporheic exchange which leads to the formation of a low-conductivity layer in the bed. Field and laboratory data reanalysis yielded simple relations, based on bed topography, to relate bed morphodynamics to the retention and remobilization of fine particles during both baseflow and floods.

This project has provided interdisciplinary training in hydrology, geomorphology, experimental methods, and image-processing methods to six undergraduates, four graduate students, and one postdoctoral associate. It also supported five U.S.-Israel student research exchanges.
